title: Sleep Positions, Pillows, and Room Temperature
content: In this episode, Matthew Walker answers questions about the best position to sleep in, the ideal type of pillow, and the optimal room temperature and body temperature for the best sleep. He also discusses the potential benefits of hammock sleeping and whether humidifiers help with sleep.

title: Sleep Disorders and Sleep Hygiene
content: Matthew Walker provides expert insight on sleep apnea, how to know if you have it, the different types, the causes, and helpful resources. He also discusses the challenges of sleep deprivation for new parents and provides advice on sleep hygiene, including napping and understanding your sleep chronotype.

title: Sleep and Lifestyle Factors
content: Matthew Walker answers questions about the effects of caffeine on sleep, how sexual activity relates to sleep quality, and whether postmenopausal women can manage their sleep problems with (and without) hormone replacement therapy. He also discusses the potential benefits and drawbacks of Wim Hof's breathing method and the impact of fasting and time-restricted eating on sleep.

title: DEC2 mutation and sleep
content: The DEC2 mutation is a genetic mutation that produces a short sleeping phenotype. People with this mutation are the acclaimed “short sleepers”. They don’t sleep as much as most people (or as much as most people should be sleeping). An important thing to point out is that the average person sleeps at 6.5 hours per night. When you take the average population and put them in a lab, they will sleep between 7.5-9.5 hours per night. As we get older, even though we may need as much sleep as we did when we were younger, physiologically we just can’t generate that sleep that we need.

title: Sleep stages and health
content: DEC2 mutation people tend to be really efficient deep sleepers (almost like they are really efficient at clearing out the adenosine that has built up throughout the day). However, they get less REM sleep. Matthew cautions anyone who thinks any stage of sleep is less important than another. Rat studies in the 1980s looked at sleep deprivation… First, they deprived rats of any sleep at all and after 9-11 days they were dead. They then selectively deprived them of either REM sleep or non-REM deep sleep. The rats that were deprived of REM sleep died almost as quickly as when they were deprived of total sleep. The rats that were deprived of deep sleep took about twice as long to die. The takeaway is that REM sleep may be more important in terms of being an essential life ingredient.

title: Sleep positions
content: If you suffer from sleep apnea/heavy snoring, Matt advises AGAINST sleeping on your back. 45% of people sleep on your side (fetal position). If you don’t have apnea or snoring, sleep on your back is best for your spinal alignment. One of the causes of sleep difficulties (outside of mental anxiety) is physical pain. And back sleep generally results in the least amount of pain.

title: Side sleeping and the glymphatic system
content: There is some evidence in animal studies that’s accumulating that side sleeping allows the glymphatic system greater clearance capacity than any other sleeping position. Another observation is that you rarely see other species exclusively sleeping on their back. It’s usually some version of side sleep and it MAY have something to do with the glymphatic system.

title: Should you consider a “sleep divorce” with your partner?
content: If you fall into this category, Matthew recommends a “sleep divorce” (which can prevent you from having a real one). The stigma is that if you’re not sleeping together well, you’re not having sex. In fact, it’s actually the opposite. By having a sleep divorce, you could increase the quality of your sleep which means… Sex hormones improve both in males and in females. Their physical relationship and the intimacy improves. The quality of their relationship improves.

title: The challenge of kids wanting to sleep in bed with their parents
content: Peter points out that from an evolutionary perspective, young kids probably never slept alone in their own part of the cave. So it’s natural for many kids to want to sleep with you. But sleeping with kids can disrupt your own sleep. The downside of having kids in the bed is that sleep quality suffers which may result in you NOT being the very best version of parents, including getting behind the wheel and drive your children around the next day while sleepy. Second component of that is it’s difficult to train them to actually gain the confidence for them to sleep by themselves and develop that skill. Don’t make it a habit. Instead have it be more of “treat” for them every once in a while.

title: Is there an ideal type of pillow?
content: Not any good scientific data out there. Matthew says this actually could be an opportunity do come in and disrupt the industry. Here are his quick thoughts on how we could find the right pillow: “You could do things like three-dimensional sort of, moving an iPhone around your head, understand what your mass is, insert your body type, etc, etc, give a few questions on your sleep preference. I think there’s a way that you could actually find the Da Vinci code to the correct pillow, or at least the correct three closest pillows. You send them out to people, and then they pick which one they want, and they send the other two back.”

title: Any data on hammock sleeping? Should adults be rocked to sleep like a baby?
content: Matt says there isn’t much about hammock sleeping specifically, but… There is something about the nature of rocking (like we do with babies). A group out of Geneva did a study. They took a bed frame and a mattress, and then they suspended it from the ceiling with four ropes at either corner.

title: Rocking motion and sleep
content: The individuals fell asleep significantly faster. They had greater amounts of deep sleep, and especially these deep sleep brainwaves. And what usually comes with those deep sleep brainwaves are something else that we call sleep spindles (short bursts of synchronous activity that are critical for learning and memory). In summary, the rocking motion… induced a physiologically reliable change in brain oscillations, and helped people fall asleep faster.

title: Optimal room temperature and body temperature for the best sleep
content: Best data that we have right now is looking at these hunter gatherer tribes. The data favors coldness for longer sleep. Between 65-67 degrees, says Matt. But the answer is more complex than that. For example, it varies from person to person. Studies have been done where they strap people into a body suit where you can exquisitely control the temperature of any part of the body. Other tips for cooling your core body temperature. Take a hot bath or a shower. All of the blood is charmed to the surface of your skin, and it radiates the heat out of the core of your body. Your core body temperature plummets once you get out. So in real life… Warm yourself up with a hot shower to radiate that heat out and get you to sleep quicker. Keep the room cool to keep your body cold throughout that middle section and later section of sleep. Then, set your thermostat to rise in the last 15 minutes of your sleep so you will wake up easier and feel less groggy.

title: Tangent on thermoregulation
content: We live within a very narrow range of body temp (about 10 degrees F). At 104-105 degrees, you’re destroying protein internally. And then anything below about 92, 93, even 94, it starts to get concerning. “You’re always on some thermal edge of a cliff in some ways.”

title: Do humidifiers help?
content: It’s surprising that we have so little data on this, says Matthew, given how many people use humidifiers next to their bed. Matthew says he thinks intuitively that “there may be something in humidity”. However, the few studies out there don’t really suggest humidity is making a difference. This study that found that holding the temperature constant and changing the humidity did not alter the sleep of the neonates. So right now, not great data overall and the data that we do have doesn’t really suggest so much of a change.

title: How do high altitudes affect sleep?
content: Altitudes above ~5,000-6,000 feet suggest people wake up more frequently, have less amount of non-rapid eye movement sleep, less deep non-REM sleep quantity, and lower quality deep sleep. We don’t have good longitudinal data to look at the question of acclamation. At some point, the body does recalibrate. We also don’t know at what altitude sleep begins to be affected, is it gradual as you move away from sea level, is it a linear change, or is it a step function change at a certain level? In 4 years of sleep data, Peter’s lowest month of heart rate variability came during a month that he spent half the month in Colorado.

title: What is the data on weighted blankets?
content: There is no good data at the moment on the efficacy of weight blankets (like the Gravity Blanket). It’s very hard to do a placebo-controlled study. There is no way for study participants to be blind to whether or not they have a 25 lb blanket on them. That said, if people subjectively feel like their sleep is improving that is a good thing. And even if the effect is a placebo, that’s not a bad thing. Peter personally uses the Gravity blanket during the winter time.

title: Caffeine—How much, and in what way, does it affect sleep?
content: Some people are more sensitive to caffeine than others. On average, taking 180-200 mg of caffeine in the evening reduced the amount of deep sleep quality in terms of electrical quality by about 20%. A 20% reduction is deep sleep quality is equivalent to aging you by 25 years. Gave people a dose of caffeine at 7:20 am, no caffeine at all throughout the day, compared it to placebo, and found something “stunning”. It dropped deep sleep by 10-12%.

title: How does sexual activity relate to sleep quality?
content: For most people (60% of women, 70% of men), sex that results in an orgasm produces better quality of sleep. It has to be sex that results in an orgasm for both partners. We move into the parasympathetic state of the nervous system, which is this sort of quiet, restful state of the nervous system. Part of that is because your heart rate will decelerate after the increase that’s happened during intercourse. Less cortisol –  the deceleration of the HR will also come with a reduction in things like cortisol. Cortisol is the enemy of sleep at night…it should be dropping to almost it’s the lowest levels just before you fall asleep and stays low in the first half of the night. Masturbation can also be a sleep aid.

title: Should we be sleeping in two phases? First sleep & second sleep?
content: In the Dickensian era, there is some evidence people would sleep in 2 shifts. At this time (in the UK and Europe), people would split shift the night and they would sleep for the first half and they would get up and eat, have sex, do social activities, etc. then go back to sleep. But were we designed to sleep this way? Matthew says there is no evidence to suggest that is how we are supposed to be sleeping. It’s more likely that we were designed to sleep 6.5-7 hrs at night and take an afternoon nap. This is common in hunter gatherer tribes.

title: Napping—Is there ideal duration? Should we be napping or not?
content: A 90 minute nap will give you one full sleep cycle and allow for some REM sleep. If you want to simply get rid of some fatigue and sleepiness, a 15-20 minute nap will be enough. Try to avoid waking up after about 45 minutes. You will be in the middle of a deep sleep cycle. You may suffer what’s called sleep inertia, which is where you may actually feel even worse. It’s a “double edged sword”. Benefits of napping may include improvement in learning and memory, cardiovascular function. Bad things about napping… Throughout the day you are building up the sleepiness chemical called adenosine. And after about 16 hours of wakefulness, you should have enough of this sleepiness chemical weighing down on you (i.e., sleep pressure) to force you into sleep at night. If you nap, you release some of that pressure which may make it harder for you to fall asleep at night. So the answer is if you can nap regularly and you’re not struggling with sleep at night, naps are just fine. But if you can’t nap regularly or especially if you’re struggling with sleep at night, the advice is do not nap, build up that healthy sleepiness.

title: Advice for new parents dealing with sleep deprivation
content: Advice for new parents, especially moms, with young babies. Nap when the child is napping (if possible). The nights will be rough and disruptive so you’ll have enough sleep pressure even if you are napping several times a day. If you have a spouse or partner that has a different sleep cycle (say you are an early riser and they are a night owl)… Try to split up the baby shifts to match that trait.

title: Understanding your sleep chronotype
content: Is your sleep chronotype genetically set? Yes, you are born with the genes for your chronotype. No matter your genes though… Your sleep timing and hours needed will change from childhood, to teen years, to adulthood. Moving high school start times… In a previous podcast, Matthew spoke extensively about the need to move high school start times to later in the day to match teens’ propensity to sleep longer and later into the morning. That’s where we see some of the greatest amounts of sleep deprivation because that’s where the greatest mismatch between school start times and wake up times happen relative to their shifted now biological circadian rhythm. Adulthood. You start to settle into your genetic sleep chronotype. Older years. Then as we get into our elder years we regress to childhood hours, go to bed early, wake up early.

title: If you drink too much alcohol in a given night, is there anything you can do to make sure your sleep isn’t wrecked?
content: If you drink too much, is there anything you can do that night be make sure your sleep isn’t wrecked? Probably not. Best thing to do is expect a bad night of sleep and plan accordingly tomorrow. In the case where you didn’t go overboard, but maybe had 1-3 drinks. Alcohol inhibit vasopressin which is an antidiuretic hormone.

title: Using Vasopressin to Improve Sleep Quality
content: Peter has used a drug called vasopressin (0.1 milligrams of DDAVP or vassopressin) to prevent sleep disruption caused by the need to pee during the night. However, this is not an over the counter medication, and taking too much can cause problems.

title: Managing Sleep Problems in Postmenopausal Women
content: Many women after menopause see a decline in their sleep quality and quantity. HRT combined with melatonin has been found to have some efficacy in improving sleep. Peter's approach with HRT uses all three hormones: Estrogen, testosterone, and progesterone. Each of them can play a role in sleep, but you can’t do it at the same time. The first step should be to try to figure out what is really triggering the sleep problems.

title: Using Wim Hof's Breathing Method to Improve Sleep Quality
content: Wim Hof's breathing method (WHM) is a combination of frequent cold exposure, breathing techniques, and meditation. It is unclear whether a daily practice of WHM could help or hinder quality of sleep.

title: Sleep Debt and Sleep Hangover
content: If this is happening in the first couple of weeks or months once you’re starting to go into sleep extension… It’s usually because you’re still trying to sleep off the debt that you’ve accumulated. Now, we can never pay back all of the sleep debt that we carry. The system has no capacity for recovering all that it lost, but it will try to sort of sleep back some of that debt. And when people start to sleep longer and they are carrying a lifetime chronic debt, then they typically have almost like a “sleep hangover” effect as they’re washing out the chronic sleep restriction. If this has been going on for five or six months… That’s something different. Figure out what your sleep chronotype. Maybe you’re sleeping the right amount now, but you’re just not placing that eight-hour window of sleep at the right point on the clock face for your specific chronotype. And that’s where you can also get some of this hangover effect too if you’re not sleeping at the right phase. You’ve got to be sleeping the right amount, but also at the right time to be in sync with your chronotype, with your circadian biology, and that can sometimes cause hangover effects as well.

title: Sleep Apnea
content: Two primary types of apnea: 1 | Obstructive sleep apnea. This is the version where your airways collapse, either partially or fully, which obstructs your ability to breath. With a partial collapse, you’ll start to get this sort of strange sound. When it fully collapses, that’s when you will get cessation of breathing typically. 2 | Central sleep apnea. There is no blockage in the airway, there is no problem with the airway at all. In fact, it seems to be a fault of the brain itself. The brain for a short period of time stops sending the signal for respiration. Note: You can also have a mix of both obstructive and central apnea. Sleep apnea is the most underdiagnosed sleep disorder. About 80% of people who have it are undiagnosed. It kills you chronically but poor sleep contributing to disease and aging. And it kills you acutely. E.g., you might fall asleep behind the wheel of your car. Think you might have sleep apnea? Take the Stop-Bang Questionnaire. If you do, find yourself a board certified sleep medicine doctor at sleepeducation.org. Do not leave sleep apnea untreated, it will shorten your lifespan, and it will certainly shorten your health span. That data is compelling. CPAP device. Stands for continuous positive airway pressure. It attempts to force open the obstructed airway with pressure. It needs to be fitted to the individual and the pressure titrated to match the needs of the person. Adherence issues: How can we improve the compliance and adherence for these devices? First, we must get really good at fitting the mask properly because… i) an uncomfortable fit will reduce adherence ii) a bad fit will not keep the proper pressure needed to open the airway. Secondly, accountability from another person or technology. Having an app or having a coach that would actually just help you check in with you every day, just give you motivation. Do we know what causes central apnea? Not a lot of data so the etiology is less clear. We know a lot more about the contributing factors of obstructive apnea. Such as men are twice as likely to have it. Overweight. Neck circumference. What is the most common type of sleep apnea in the population? More common for obstructive than central.

title: Using Apneic Hypoxemic Index vs Oxygen Desaturation Index
content: Peter prefers using the ODI with a 4% cutoff. The mortality data says more than ~25 4% ODIs per hour is a really significant predictor of mortality. Peter says this information helps him communicate with the patient the severity of this and why we really have to act on this sort of thing.

title: Apnea Hypopnea Index
content: Apnea hypopnea index looks at the number of times that you have a true apneic event where you have a cessation of breathing. A moderate degree of apnea would be a cessation of breath between 10 to 15 per hour. That would be like someone coming into your bedroom and strangling your neck until you stopped breathing 80-100 times in a single night. And then I’m going to expect you to wake up the next day and feel good and go to work and perform well and be a good partner to your wife or husband? “That’s ridiculous…but that’s what that disorder is doing.”

title: Sleep Trackers and Oxygen Saturation
content: Fitbit devices have the capacity built in (but may not have unlocked it yet). Apple may be looking into this, but again, I have no insider knowledge. Matt says it would be a huge deal if sleep devices could do this… The but obviously concern would be the accuracy.

title: Sleep Eating
content: It is a real condition. It’s part of a set of conditions that we call parasomnias. These are things that happen around sleep, not necessarily during sleep itself. Parasomnias typically happen from deep sleep (not during dream sleep like most people think) when you get a jolt of the sympathetic nervous system activity. You technically wake up, but you’re neither fully awake nor fully asleep and you start to act out routine behaviors (i.e., Sleep walking, sleep talking). But a more rare variation is sleep eating. There’s not too much we can do, unfortunately. Talk to a sleep doctor. There may be a few pharmacological approaches out there but not great treatment outcomes right now. The doctor on this video says clinical hypnosis can help with this.

title: Matt's Changes to Society to Improve Sleep
content: Step 1: A public health campaign needs to be the first step at the government level. There are great campaigns for things like drink driving, safe sex, risky behavior, even physical activity, eating. But where is the policy for sleep? Step 2: Institutions. A great example would be medicine. You see in a doctor’s office posters that would describe here are “8 ways that you can improve your diet” or “4 ways that you can improve your physical activity”. Where’s the chart that describes tips for better sleep? Step 3: Education. In school, we get lectures on safe sex, drink and driving, etc. Where was that lecture for sleep education? “It is so fundamental. It’s such a huge part of that developing teenager’s life, they should be given that. It should be given early on.” Matt wants to help create an education curriculum that is palatable to young audiences so we stop this sort of “parent to child transmission of sleep neglect and sleep ignorance”.

title: Retrospective Damage vs Prospective Benefit
content: So let’s think about cancer.

title: Effects of Sleep on Cancer Risk
content: If I put you on one night of four hours of sleep, I can drop your natural killer cell count on average for this group by about 70%. The following day after that short sleep, your vulnerability to cancer is presumably going to be increased because of that drop in NK cells. Now, getting lots and lots of sleep the following night is not going to go back in time and bend the arrow of time back on itself and wash away that cancer risk. Instead, what it’s going to mean is that for the day after you’ve got good sleep, your natural killer cell count is going to be presumably back up. Therefore you’re now de-risking your cancer risk by way of getting good sleep.

title: Sleep and Aging
content: In the previous AMA, Matt discussed how less sleep is associated with an increase in biomarkers of age. But does poor sleep really cause faster aging? Firstly, Matt admits that sleep and aging is a bi-direction system. It goes both ways. I.e., aging causes poor sleep, but poor sleep also causes aging. But the question then becomes… Is the traffic flowing more dominantly in one direction than another?

title: Causality of Sleep Studies
content: So, when does Matthew feel comfortable making claims of causality? Only when he sees evidence in epidemiological studies, experimental human studies, and experimental animal studies. That’s the point where you start to feel comfortable speaking about causality. Ways to test causality: First in people, we can take someone who has no anxiety, take sleep away, hold all of the factors constant and see if anxiety is induced. That’s causal manipulation. But let’s be self-critical there: Perhaps it’s just the stress of being sleep deprived that causes the anxiety and not the lack of sleep itself. Do an animal study where you can actually remove the adrenal glands to therefore remove the cortisol response that is producing the stress. You can hold the stress response constant and you can deprive them of sleep and you can look at anxious behavior, and you’ll see the same thing.

title: Medicated Sleep vs No Sleep
content: For someone struggling with severe insomnia, is it better to get almost no sleep or to take an antihistamine or mild benzos as a sleep aid? Matt admits that this is a very tough question. Firstly, people very quickly build a tolerance to antihistamines. And then they can typically have rebound insomnia when they come off of antihistamines and/or benzos. Matt suggests first going through Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBTI). If that doesn’t work, then “I don’t know the right answer to that”. In 2016, the American College of Physicians made the recommendation that sleeping pills must no longer be the first line recommended treatment for insomnia due to their harmful (even fatal) consequences and that the first treatment must be CBTI.

title: CBD for Sleep
content: CBD was discussed on previous episodes of The Drive with Matt Walker. But people are reportedly having some success with CBD for sleep. But be careful, it’s the “wild wild west” with OTC CBD… “there’s not good regimented quality control”.

title: Short term use of benzos for anxiety and insomnia
content: In a crisis situation, short use of benzos is not an unreasonable choice (Matt agrees). In many cases, anxiety can drive insomnia (and insomnia can then also drive anxiety). But in cases of anxiety being the prime driver, short term use of benzos may help to break the cycle. Peter finds it’s not that hard to get people off them and back into a routine.

title: Vivid dreaming and sleep disruption
content: Vivid dreams do not seem to disrupt sleep in terms of quantity of quality (even though they may feel sort of exhausting). Trauma dreams (i.e., in PTSD patients) do, in fact, disrupt sleep.

title: Binaural beats and inducing deep sleep
content: Matt says that these “binaural beats” or other downloaded sound files don’t have any good scientific studies that have really demonstrated efficacy. Studies have been done where people will actually measure your deep sleep brainwaves. They will use these short bursts of sound that try to predict when that next deep sleep brainwave is going to arrive. And at the sort of “stroke of midnight” they will play the auditory tone. And if you do that, what you can actually induce is a larger size, a bigger amplitude of deep sleep brainwave activity. And you can get some memory benefits from that. But here’s the problem… First, if your timing is off and you’re striking at 6 rather than midnight, you’re actually going to inhibit your deep sleep brainwaves. Secondly, if you’re doing it all night, the brain will actually start to fight back. At best, it becomes ineffective. At worst, it could become sleep disruptive.

title: Fasting and sleep quality
content: Matthew has said in a previous episode that fasting, from an evolutionary perspective, would reduce our sleep demand to give us more time to forage for food. But in Peter’s experience with fasting, he finds it produces an amazing state of sleep (albeit slightly less duration) but better in quality. Does this surprise Matthew? Yes and no, he says. He says “no” because we don’t really have good data. The only decent data we have is with people practicing Ramadan where their REM sleep is negatively affected. Peter points out that Ramadan isn’t true fasting it’s just fasting during the day time and they feed at night time so they are almost in a “hyper fed state”. The Ramadan data is probably better at helping us learning something about meal timing’s effect on sleep for someone practicing time-restricted feeding and suggests and earlier window of eating is better.

title: Polyphasic sleep and the Uberman schedule
content: It’s a version of polyphasic sleep where sleep for short bursts (45-90 mins) then be awake for a couple hours and then just cycle on and off throughout the day. Kind of like sleeping like an infant. There is no good evidence in adults that that is at all how we should be sleeping.
